beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: Iowa Wind and Rock. Winterset, Iowa. 340 mi. Iowa Wind and Rock is 340 miles of honest Iowa gravel: crushed limestone roads rolling through endless agricultural land with zero shelter from wind. The terrain itself is moderate. 8 thousand feet of elevation spread thin via constant short climbs. but the format is brutal. You'll ride 30-50 hours continuously, crossing into overnight hours, navigating independently with GPS, and resupplying at small-town gas stations. The wind is THE defining feature: 10-20 mph sustained headwinds and crosswinds for hours. The constant rolling terrain means you never truly rest. always climbing or grinding into wind. River valley crossings add scenic variety and punchy elevation. The self-supported format strips away all external motivation. No crowds. No aid stations. No teammates. Just you, Iowa backroads, and the mental test of keeping pedals turning for 40+ hours when quitting would be easy.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: The numbers. All fourteen of them. Length. 5 out of 5. Ultra distance. Bring lights and a plan. 340+ miles with 34-hour cutoffs separate finishers from the majority who DNF. Adventure. 5 out of 5. Adventure is the entire point. Ultra-remote farmland where "we never passed a single gas station the entire route other than our pre-planned 3 stops," notes Wilco. Experience. 5 out of 5. Transformative. People come back different. 340 miles through Iowa farmland will rewire your brain permanently. Climate. 4 out of 5. Weather is part of the race strategy. April in Iowa delivers extreme variability from year to year. Value. 4 out of 5. One of the better deals in gravel. Free entry with donations accepted makes this exceptional value for 340 miles of organized suffering. Logistics. 3 out of 5. Adequate. The word was invented for this. Secret course revealed at start forces navigation with cue sheets on 340 miles of Iowa grid roads. Race Quality. 3 out of 5. Solid production value. Organized checkpoints and volunteer support manage the 340-mile route well, but course conditions create race-ending hazards. Community. 3 out of 5. Good vibes. Riders actually talk to each other. Small fields create "deep respect for anyone that shows up to even toe the line," notes Wilco about the understated atmosphere.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Also Scored
beats.narration: And the rest of the scorecard. Expenses. 3 out of 5. Mid-range expenses. Budget a proper race weekend. Technicality. 2 out of 5. Your road bike might survive. Might. Elevation. 2 out of 5. Rolling terrain. Nothing that'll break you. Prestige. 2 out of 5. Regional reputation. The locals know. Field Depth. 2 out of 5. Enough competition to keep you honest. Altitude. 1 out of 5. Low altitude. Breathe easy.

strengths: 340 miles is genuine ultra-endurance challenge—tests limits beyond typical racing
Self-supported format teaches true independence and problem-solving under fatigue
Iowa Gravel Series organization provides solid GPS track and safety support
Resupply at Iowa small towns adds human connection and real-world adventure feel
Reasonable value ($150-200) for ultra-endurance format with tracking and finisher awards

beats.label: WEAKNESSES
beats.visual: Weaknesses list with warning visual treatment
beats.editing_note: MIDPOINT RE-ENGAGEMENT. This is ~55% through. Open with burst sequence (quick cuts, warning sounds). Then deliver weaknesses honestly. Preview what's coming: 'Now, should you actually do this race?' [RIFF HERE] at the transition.

weaknesses: Wind exposure for 30-50 hours is psychologically crushing—constant headwinds break morale
April weather unpredictability: rain/mud can make course unrideable, cold tests gear
340 miles is significantly longer than most ultras—bonking at Mile 200 leaves 140 miles remaining
Self-supported format means no external motivation, aid stations, or crowds—purely internal battle
Limited national prestige and small field depth—not attracting competitive racing atmosphere

logistics: Fly into: DSM - 45min drive to Winterset. Rental car useful for area exploration and post-race flexibility.

Lodging: Winterset, IA has limited motels/Airbnbs. book early. Des Moines has more lodging options. Book flexible dates: finishers arrive Sunday-Monday depending on pace. Consider post-race recovery lodging for 1-2 nights.

beats.label: VERDICT
beats.narration: Verdict: Wind-Blasted Odyssey. You need 200+ mile experience and the mental fortitude to grind through 40+ hours of constant wind exposure across endless farm roads. This isn't about watts. it's about navigation skills, self-sufficiency, and accepting that you'll question every life choice around Mile 200. Skip it if you've never done overnight riding or think Iowa looks flat and easy.
beats.editing_note: CLOSE THE MAIN LOOP. 0.5s silence before verdict. Tier badge slams in. Avatar delivers final take. DO NOT signal 'wrapping up' — maintain energy.

beats.label: ALTERNATIVES
beats.narration: If Iowa Wind and Rock isn't quite right for you. Dirty Kanza DK200 gives you the ultra-endurance challenge with better support and more prestige. While Gravel Worlds in Nebraska delivers similar Midwest suffering with a more established field. Both will test you without the navigation headaches of true self-support.
